questions.text: Several colonic polyps were incidentally detected on a screening colonoscopy in a 51-year-old male patient. He was further evaluated and diagnosed with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP). Which of the following defective DNA repair mechanisms is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in MUTYH Associated Polyposis (MAP) is DNA base excision repair (BER). Its function is to remove base uracil from the DNA.

Base lesions spontaneously occur in the DNA by various mechanisms including deamination, oxidation, and alkylation. This damage causes the conversion of single bases in the DNA such as cytosine, adenine, and guanine bases to uracil, hypoxanthine, and xanthine respectively, thereby threatening the integrity of the DNA. This damage is corrected by base excision repair. 

Base excision repair may occur in the nuclei as well as in the mitochondria. It includes the following major enzymatic steps-

  • DNA glycosylase- It recognizes the damaged base and removes it leaving an abasic site/ AP-site (apurinic/apyrimidinic site). 
  • AP -endonucleases excise the basic sugar and cleave the DNA strand. 
  • DNA polymerase β (Pol β) add the appropriate nucleotides 
  • Ligase seals the strand and completes the repair.

questions.text: A child presents with severe neurological symptoms,  polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, and cerebellar ataxia. His symptoms regress with restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. What can be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease which occurs due to a defect in the alpha oxidation of fatty acids.

Refsum’s disease: It is a neurologic disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of phytanic acid in the peroxisome. The enzyme phytanoyl CoA oxidase(Alpha hydroxylase) is defective. Accumulation of phytanic acid will affect membrane function, protein prenylation, and gene expression.

The patient presents with severe neurological symptoms, polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, and cerebellar ataxia. Management includes restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. Sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, and green leafy vegetables should be avoided.

Other options:

Option B: Usher syndrome - Sensorineural deafness + Retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C: Zellweger Syndrome  - also known as Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome 

Caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes -also called peroxins involved in Peroxisome Biogenesis /Peroxisomal enzymes themselves 
Biochemical findings :

    • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids
    • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
    • marked reduction of plasmalogens

Option D: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is an accumulation of very large chain fatty acids in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and the testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with swelling of joints, a hoarse voice, and subcutaneous nodules. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is seen. The child is diagnosed with Farber's disease. Which enzyme defect is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Farber's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme ceramidase. This leads to the accumulation of ceramide, resulting in the characteristic clinical features of Farber disease.

Key clinical features of Farber disease:

  • Hoarse voice: a hallmark symptom resulting from laryngeal involvement.
  • Joint Pain and Swelling: Resembling arthritis due to granulomas in the joints.
  • Subcutaneous Nodules
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Developmental Delay: due to progressive neurodegeneration

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids plays a key role in the generation and transmission of visual impulses in the retina?
questions.solution:
Phosphatidylinositol (PI) is responsible for signal transmission as well as the generation of impulses in the retina. 

Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.

Visual pigments are a type of G-protein-coupled receptors. The receptor protein, known as opsin, is locked in its inactive state by 11-cis retinal. Isomerization and photo-excitation result in the activation of G-protein and the production of cyclic GMP. Transducin serves as the G-protein specifically within the retina.   The nerve impulse that is produced in the retina is then conveyed to the visual centres in the brain. The signal is ended through the process of phosphorylation, specifically targeting a serine residue on the activated rhodopsin. This phosphorylation is carried out by an enzyme called rhodopsin kinase. The purpose of this phosphorylation is to allow the inhibitory protein beta-arrestin to connect to the rhodopsin and deactivate it.

The phos­phorylation of membrane-bound phosphatidylinositol(PI) produces polyphosphoinositides such as phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).

The degradation of PIP2 by phospholipase C occurs in response to the binding of a variety of neurotransmitters, hormones, and growth factors to receptors on the cell membrane. The degrada­tion products are :

  • Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) which mediates the mobilization of intracellular calcium
  • Diacylglycerol (DAG) which activates protein kinase C

Both of these act synergistically to evoke specific cellular responses thus accomplishing signal transmission.

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with confusion, memory loss, and agitation. On examination, he is disoriented and horizontal nystagmus is noted. Which of the following enzyme markers can aid the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
The features of confusion, memory loss, and horizontal nystagmus in a chronic alcoholic are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused due to deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1). This can be diagnosed by erythrocyte transketolase assay.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a water-soluble vitamin, required for carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is its coenzyme form and is required for the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase 
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

Beriberi - anorexia, dyspepsia, heaviness, peripheral neuropathy, and weakness (dry beriberi) or with cardiovascular features like edema, palpitations, breathlessness, distended neck veins (wet beriberi)

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with chronic alcohol abuse which lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

Korsakoff's syndrome is a neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by confabulation and memory defects. Immediate memory is generally maintained but short-term memory is diminished.

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 1-month-old child who is being exclusively breastfed develops bluish discoloration of skin, breathing difficulty, and a soft cry. On evaluation, cardiomegaly is detected. The mother, who is accustomed to consuming polished rice, has no symptoms of illness. Which of the following vitamins may be deficient in the mother?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of cyanosis, dyspnea, and aphonia, seen here as bluish discoloration of skin, breathing difficulty, and a soft or weak cry, associated with cardiomegaly in a breastfed infant of a mother accustomed to consuming polished-rice, is suggestive of Infantile Beriberi, due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency in the mother.

Infantile beriberi occurs in breastfed infants of thiamine-deficient mothers, wherein the mother may be asymptomatic but the child presents with the symptoms and signs of cyanosis, dyspnea, aphonia and cardiomegaly. Untreated infantile beriberi may be fatal within a few weeks. Thiamine deficiency causes beriberi, commonly seen in low socio-economic status where polished rice which is thiamine deficient, is consumed. The condition may present in three varieties:

1. Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults.

2. Wet beriberi results due to cardiac and renal dysfunction which leads to fluid accumulation. It is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema.

3. Infantile beriberi, as described above.

Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Treatment with thiamine leads to resolution of neurologic and cardiac symptoms within 24-48 hours. Treatment of patients with mild beriberi with thiamine (5 mg/day) is satisfactory. Severely ill children should receive 10 mg intravenously twice daily. 

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin deficiency can present with cheilosis, but it does not typically cause pedal edema and cardiomegaly.

Option C: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, anemia, and dermatitis but is not associated with pedal edema, cardiomegaly, and cheilosis.

Option D: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not associated with pedal edema, cardiomegaly, and cheilosis.

questions.text: During an autopsy of a man with a suspected case of poisoning, you observe the presence of a bitter almond odor. Which of the following changes is associated with this poisoning?
questions.solution:
Complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) is blocked by cyanide, which has a characteristic bitter almond odour in case of poisoning. In addition, an increase in the mixed venous saturation of the blood can be observed as there is reduced oxygen delivery by the RBCs to the tissues. 

Complexes of ETC   Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin A, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase TTFA (thenoyltrifluoroacetone), carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL (British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV: Cyt c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

The following image shows different compounds inhibiting the different components in an electron transport chain.

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2). The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Other options :

Option A: There would be an increase in NADH and not an increase in NAD+ as the body in the absence of oxygen tries to generate ATP through glycolysis, thus leading to the accumulation of both pyruvate and NADH.

Option C: This patient can develop metabolic acidosis which would lead to increased reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal tubular cells of the kidney.

Option D: Cyanide tends to cause inhibition of complex 4 of the electron transport chain causing a depletion of the proton gradient.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with a history of impaired vision and severe photophobia. On examination, he has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue eyes. A disorder due to deficiency in the enzyme tyrosinase is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism. 

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterised by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase further acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. 

Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. 

Other options-

Option B- Tyrosinemia type 1 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical findings include cirrhosis, liver failure, rickets, failure to thrive, peripheral neuropathy, and boiled cabbage odour. 

Option C- Tyrosinemia type 2 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability. 

Option D- Homocystinuria is caused due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Clinical findings include lens dislocation, thrombotic vascular disease, intellectual disability, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn is referred to you with recurrent vomiting and diarrhea. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Based on further evaluation, a diagnosis of classical galactosemia is made. This baby is most susceptible to sepsis caused by:
questions.solution:
Infants with classical galactosemia are susceptible to recurrent sepsis caused by Escherichia coli.

Classical galactosemia is caused to deficient galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. The enzyme is responsible for the conversion of galactose 1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate in the metabolism of galactose.  

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

questions.text: A child born with a rare genetic disorder presented with failure to thrive and susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic, viral, and fungal infections. His blood reports showed lymphopenia and a diagnosis of SCID was suspected. He was advised to stay in a protective 'bubble' as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disease in question?

choices.text: The X-linked form is due to the deficiency of  adenosine deaminase
Defective humoral and cell-mediated immune responses

questions.solution:
X-linked SCID is the most common form where there is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. The given clinical scenario and the image of a child in a protective bubble (Bubble boy disease) are suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). 

 Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterized by:

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.
  • Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R.

Types of SCID:

X-linked SCID

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

It can be associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ deficiency confers (severe) combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out V(D)J recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Note:

The deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme was the first pathophysiologic condition to be treated by gene therapy. In1990, Dr. William French Anderson introduced a new copy of this gene, which was carried on a retroviral vector, into a 4-year-old girl suffering from severe combined immunodeficiency (bubble boy disease).

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient with short stature, disproportionate spine, barrel chest with pectus carinatum and a short neck came to the OPD. On evaluation, a diagnosis of lysosomal storage disorder is made. The glycosaminoglycan involved in the condition is a prominent component of which among the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses IV and the glycosaminoglycan involved is chondroitin sulfate, which is a prominent component of cartilage.

It is composed of repeating units of N-acetyl galactosamine and glucuronic acid (GAG).

In this condition, the affected individuals survive into adulthood with normal faces and intellect. Short stature with a disproportionate spine, barrel chest with pectus carinatum, and short neck and limb abnormalities may be present.

Some important features of chondroitin sulfate are as follows:

  • The most abundant GAG in the body and is seen in the cartilage, CNS, and bone
  • They are located at sites of calcification in endochondral bone and are a major component of cartilage.
  • They are found in high amounts in the extracellular matrix of the central nervous system.

Other options:

Option A: Keratan sulfate I and II are the GAGs in the cornea. It is also found in cartilage and loose connective tissue. It is the only GAG that does not contain any uronic acid. The repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Option C: Heparan sulfate is the GAG present in the kidney basement membrane, where it plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration. It is also found in the skin. It contains repeating units of sulfated glucosamine and glucuronic acid.

Option D: Hyaluronic acid is the GAG present in synovial fluid. It is also found in skin, bone, cartilage, vitreous humor, and embryonic tissues. It contains repeating units of  N-acetyl glucosamine and glucuronic acid. It plays a role in morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid along with chondroitin sulfates in cartilage contribute to its compressibility.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes will show reduced activity in a person who is fasting?
questions.solution:
During fasting, there is increased glucagon release. This causes the production of cAMP, and subsequent activation of cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This protein kinase has two functions:

  • Activation of fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • Inactivation of phosphofructokinase-2

Both these actions reduce the amount of fructose 2,6 bisphosphate and thus inhibit glycolysis and move the needle of glucose metabolism toward gluconeogenesis. Pyruvate carboxylase and fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase are enzymes catalyzing steps of gluconeogenesis, and are thus stimulated during fasting state.

questions.text: A woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.  She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic.  Urine Rothera's test is positive. Which of the following tissues cannot utilize the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased here is ketone bodies and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  • β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  • Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  • Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

  • Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.
  • Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside
  • Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta hydroxy butyrate.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male baby presents with a history of fever, irritability, and vomiting. On examination, there is moderate hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of serum transaminases and elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which enzyme is deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and laboratory findings are diagnostic of tyrosinemia type I and the enzyme deficient is fumarylacetoacetate hydroxylase (FAH).

Tyrosinemia type I or Hepatorenal tyrosinemia is caused by FAH deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disease, caused by a defective FAH gene. This results in the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone which are metabolites of tyrosine degradation. The tissues most affected are hepatic, renal, and nervous tissues. The manifestations of these can be seen in the form of an acute hepatic crisis, such as in this case. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

Boiled cabbage odor may be present in classical type 1 tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of elevated levels of succinylacetone in urine or blood. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC) which reduces the formation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone by inhibiting the degradation of tyrosine. However, this increases the plasma levels of tyrosine. A diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine is also prescribed to patients.

Other options:

Option B: Tyrosine aminotransferase is deficient in tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome or oculocutaneous tyrosinemia). It is also an autosomal recessive disease that results in hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. The laboratory finding here is marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid. The treatment here also involves a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Option C: 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability. The liver function is generally normal. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to deficiency of 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase.

Option D: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria. It manifests as progressive intellectual disability. The diagnosis is made by measurement of plasma phenylalanine levels or by detecting phenyl ketones in the urine. A diet low in phenylalanine is the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient came with complaints of weight loss, lethargy, polyuria, and polyphagia. During the blood sample collection for plasma glucose estimation in this patient, a vacutainer shown in the below image is used.  Which of the following glycolytic enzymes is inhibited by the content in the vacutainer?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a grey vacutainer. It is used to collect blood samples for plasma glucose estimation. Since it contains sodium fluoride, the fluoride will inhibit the glycolytic enzyme enolase.

Grey vacutainer contains sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate. Potassium oxalate binds to calcium and inhibits coagulation.

 Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes:

  • Fluoride inhibits the enzyme enolase which is responsible for the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate.
  • Iodoacetate inhibits the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase which is responsible for the conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate. This action of iodoacetate helps in anticancer activity.
  • Arsenate inhibits 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase. 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase converts  1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerates. Arsenate competes with inorganic phosphate (Pi) in this reaction to give 1-arseno-3-phosphoglycerate which undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis to 3-phosphoglycerate without forming ATP.

questions.text:
A patient who is a painter by profession presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and bluish-black discoloration of gums are observed. All of the following are features of this poisoning, except __________.

ALA - Delta-aminolevulinic acid

choices.text: Microcytic hypochromic anemia with basophilic stippling of erythrocytes seen in peripheral smear
Elevated levels of ALA and coproporphyrinogen in urine
Elevated levels of porphobilinogen in blood

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of lead poisoning. Porphobilinogen is not elevated in blood in lead poisoning.  

Lead inhibits the enzymes delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase and ferrochelatase, which are involved in heme synthesis. ALA is converted to porphobilinogen by ALA dehydratase, which is inhibited by lead. So, porphobilinogen levels are decreased in lead poisoning.

Clinical features of chronic lead poisoning include facial pallor, anemia, basophilic stippling of red cells, blue line in the gums, and retinal stippling. In the later phase, the findings are colic abdominal pain, constipation, nerve palsy, encephalopathy, and disturbance of the genito-urinary and cardiovascular systems. Laboratory findings include the following:

  • An elevated serum lead level
  • An elevated level of protoporphyrin in blood and elevated ALA and coproporphyrinogen in urine
  • Microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling in peripheral smear due to ineffective heme synthesis

questions.text: A bodybuilder who does strenuous exercises went to the doctor with complaints of muscle cramps. Muscle cramps are due to the accumulation of lactic acid. Which of the following cycles is responsible for preventing lactate accumulation in the muscle?
questions.solution:
Cori's cycle is responsible for preventing lactate accumulation in the muscle.

The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles, back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle. Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and erythrocytes. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Lactic acid which accumulates in the muscle after strenuous muscle exercises enter Cori's cycle. This process prevents the accumulation of lactate thereby preventing muscle cramps.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called as glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from muscle as it is the major substrate for gluconeogenesis. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Krebs cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle, is the final common oxidative pathway that oxidizes acetyl CoA to CO2. It is the source of reduced co-enzymes that provide the substrate for the respiratory chain. It also acts as the link between catabolic and anabolic pathways (amphibolic role).

Option D- The Krebs-Henseleit cycle (urea cycle) is also known as the ornithine cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver. The overall reaction may be summarized as NH3 + CO2 + Aspartate → Urea + Fumarate.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Gene and cellular therapy is being used to treat all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Gene and cellular therapy is being used to treat all the above-mentioned conditions except Down’s syndrome.

Gene therapy, a revolutionary breakthrough in modern medicine, aims to introduce a missing gene or replace a defective gene in an affected individual. 

The first curative effect of gene therapy was noticed with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Other conditions where it can be applied include spinal muscular atrophy, transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia, and chronic granulomatous disease.

Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy, a type of cellular therapy is practiced in refractory or relapsing cancers such as B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and B cell lymphoma. It cannot be used in chromosomal disorders like Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21).

This is generally carried out with the help of a gene delivery vehicle such as a virus or lipid nanoparticle.

questions.text: A biochemist wanted to study the difference in gene expression between a cancer cell and a normal cell. He used the following method shown in the image. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The method shown in the image is called microarray analysis. 

It can be used to study mutations in DNA and variations in gene expression.

It consists of a slide with tiny spots of DNA called a DNA (or gene) chip. For studying gene expression, mRNA is taken from the sample and then its complementary DNA (cDNA) is made. This cDNA from the normal cell is labeled with green fluorescence, and the cDNA from the cancer cell is labeled with red fluorescence. Then, both are allowed to hybridize with the DNA on the chip.

Interpretation:

  • Black spots represent no expression by both normal and cancer cells.
  • Red spots represent more expression by the cancer cells.
  • Green spots represent more expression by normal cells.
  • Yellow spots represent equal expression by both cells.

Using the microarray technique, the differing patterns of gene expression between two types of cells can be analyzed.

Option B - A northern blot only measures mRNA production from one gene at a time.
Option C - Southern blot can only analyze DNA not the products of DNA expression.
Option d - Western blot measures protein production.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was admitted to your hospital with multiple pigmented papular lesions on his face, neck, forearm, and corneal injection following the exposure to the sun as shown below.  On further investigations, cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinoma were found. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple lesions on the sun-exposed area and multiple cutaneous malignancies are suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin.

XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.
